Comments_List:
- Theoretical backgrounds and actual implementations of many machine learning methods.
- Experience with some useful machine learning packages in python and R

This course was very helpful in developing basic insights of machine learning and data mining. I enjoyed the Nature language processing and deep learning overview of this course. This course also helped me gain skills in R and Python programming and gave me the knowledge to approach machine learning problems in a more rigorous way.
I learned a lot about ML, both the theory, as well as the application.

This course helped me develop a better, global understanding of the machine learning field and research. It gave me confidence in coding complex problems in R and python. Gave me a better intuition on how algorithms work and the thinking for a problem in machine learning (with the terms of cross-validation, variance/bias tradeoff, train and test set...). The models we studied were well explained and the homework were always relevant to the material seen in class.

The word applied is a lie. This course is very theoretical and I wouldnt recommend if you were hoping to find practical data mining skills.
The only thing I can remember after this course is lasso ridge tree random forest.
basic understanding of common machine learning methods and algorithms and how to implement them in R/python
machine learning applications in R and Python; when to use certain methods; outstanding issues and questions in on-going ML research
r, python, statistics
A good knowledge and insights of machine learning. It is well-organized.
Strong overview of machine learning and the intuition behind algorithms. Implementation in R and Python.
R programming, machine learning algorithms
a lot of machine learning with mathmatics
Good introductory course for machine learning with a lot of applied works to better understand the course.
I became familiar with various commonly used machine learning methods.
big ideas and fundamental knowledge of machine learning.
Theorical and practical machine learning skills.
Main topics in machine learning including linear regression, decision tree, topic modelling, etc. Used both R and python to build models.
a lot of practical use of data mining
R machine learning
statistic fundamentals, machine learning strategy, more insights on how models work
machine learning basics, mainly about classic classification
It is an introduction class to machine learning. I learned maths, programming, everything.
Many insights into machine learning and underlying math!! very helpful for machine learning interested students!
R programming and basic machine learning techniques.

Modeling. 
Basic idea of statistics. 
Various methods in machine learning.
Lots of machine learning algorithms. Applications in different fields including image processing and topic modeling. Programming language R and Python.

Enhanced data science skills and machine learning knowledge

machine learning
topic modelings
python
The best thing I learned in Yale.

Strength:
This course covers many aspects with detailed information and provides solid theoretical backgrounds, which facilitates both understanding and application.

Weakness:
Some of the assignments contain many repetitive work. Maybe more innovative tasks with fewer labor could be included.

This course gives a good overview of the machine learning area and is good intro level course for anyone who wants to get into the field. The weakness of this course might be that all of it is not in python. Also some assignments had a lot of starter code which was both good and bad because I felt like I did not have to do much in term of coding.
I feel it can be improved by maybe making all assignments in python.

I thought that the homework was really helpful for learning the material, as well as the help available on the homework. Sometimes, the concepts explained in lecture were hard to grasp, and it would have been helpful to have multiple explanations.

This class was amazing in the sense that it gave a broad overview of Machine learning. The homework were also very relevant to the course, and the textbook particularly useful and well suited to work on R. Sometimes the homework were challenging and I felt that the TA hours were not always helpful. I spent a lot of time trying to debug the code, but I guess that's a part everyone has to go through to learn how to code well. But asking questions on piazza was a nice way to get help. I did wish the grading was a bit fairer, I sometimes didn't understand why I got some points taken off (the questions in the homework were sometimes not explicit enough). That was a hard courses but I felt like I progressed a lot. It was nice to be able to do some data analysis  in the homework, before doing some machine learning algorithms on it.
Too difficult, too time consuming. Professor is nice though. But sometimes its too fast that its difficult to understand.

the beginning of the course was easier to follow. The lectures and the content seemed more concrete and were explained more fully than the topics towards the end of the course. I have a better understanding of the methods we discussed at the start of course than those covered towards the end.
strengths- covers a lot of useful material; weakness- varying levels of engagement and helpfulness from TAs
more practical sessions with coding in class (or formal sessions instead of office hours) would be helpful.
I think the strength is that it is well-organized and instructor made it easy to follow.
Great course. I think the style grading on problem sets was rather harsh. Other than that, no complaints.
The professor is amazing. The homework doesnt give a lot of hints
A lot of applied exercises to better understand the basic concept for machine learning.

The professors seemed passionate about student learning, but it was challenging to make the content approachable across the range of student backgrounds in the course. It would have been very helpful to have a textbook or detailed set of notes to read that would thoroughly explain the material. Instead, I usually had to google around for explanations of different course concepts, with varying success. I think that the problem sets had value but were too expansive and lengthy. Also, I came into the class with significant experience with R, and yet even I found that too much valuable time was spent messing around with getting data into the right format and wading through package documentation. To maximize learning, just tell students exactly which packages to use, how to get the data in the right format, etc. There will be time later in internships and jobs for learning R the slow way.

If possible, future students may find it interesting to hear from a machine learning ethics expert in a guest lecture.
Hopefully the assignments use Python instead of R.
I lot of background of statistics and programming is required.

The statistical part of the course material is kind of challenging for students with limited background in stats like me. Maybe more resource to study these materials would be helpful. Overall I enjoyed the assignment and I think they are well organized. Lectures are also intriguing.
too theoretical

weakness is that it's way too hard for the first few assignments, which consumed us too much time.
strength is that the course really teaches me underlying principles of machine learning and data mining.

Focus too much on the math
The first few assignments workload too heavy.
It is technically an advanced class but there is only one level machine learning class, thus it might be difficult for beginners. It might be better to have separate level machine learning class.

strengths: this course strengthens your machine learning basics, especially in mathematics way. the professor is prestigious in ML and NLP, we learned a lot.
weaknesses: some assignments(like LDA) have too many math involved, it hard for a programmer in CS to handle these...
Mathematical details are not fully understood by students, just general ideas.
N/A

Strengths: Good course arrangements and abundant knowledge
Weakness: Assignments are first improperly too much; some workloads are repetitive and not very useful
Could be fluent in programming languages like R and Python.

strengths: concise and comprehensive
weaknesses: maybe provide more relevant materials for better understanding. The class notes sometimes are a little bit confusing
Yes. It is a very good introductory course for anyone who plan to work on data science.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to know more about machine learning and data science. This course is also a good fit for those who are not just amateurs in the area but have a fair idea of the concepts. It is a nice challenging course that will stimulate anyone's mind to think in the right direction to solve ML problems.
Yes. I would explain to them that they will learn some really helpful and interesting ML that they can likely apply in some future task, or area of their work/life.

I'd recommend this course to students if they want to have a better understanding of Machine Learning. However, the courseload for this class is important, and it requires having the foundations in statistics and some programming experience.
No.

Yes. While I do not fully understand why some of the methods we covered work, I have gained an appreciation for the complexity of the methods and have a better sense of how much and really how little many of those who use these methods really know about them. As companies (and governments?) move more towards using these methods, I think part of being an informed and healthily skeptical citizen is to have some understanding of how the information being collected about us is used.
yes, this was a great introductory course
Yes. A good course to start for those interested in ML
Yes, I would recommend.
Yes! Well taught and gives a strong foundation for machine learning.
Yes.
Yes. Its necessary for people who want to be a data scientist.
Yes if anyone wants to understand machine learning- relevant knowledge.

It depends on the student. I developed familiarity with a variety of common machine learning methods, but I didn't develop the nuanced understanding that I was hoping for. I ultimately felt that I lacked the mathematics and statistical background to fully benefit from the material, and I would have been better served taking more introductory courses first. My grade in the class will probably be around the class average or slightly better, which may mean that many students were in a similar situation.
Yes. I would recommend this course to those who have some programming and statistics background and want to learn the big ideas / methods of machine learning.
Definitely. Just take this course in the fall semester.
Yes, I would recommend this to students who are interested in machine learning. I absolutely learned a lot from the course even though I have taken a similar course during my undergraduate study.
yes
Yes
Yes. it is practical and useful.
Yes. Very interesting and helpful course overall.
definitely, this is the best course for a student with interest in ML
Yes
Yes. This is a fundamental course in machine learning.

Yes. this is a good course for the entry level of statistical methods of machine learning. Helpful to build a basic frame of knowledge.
Yes!
Yes. It is a great help for you to learn things about machine learning and will be helpful for your future career life
